Reddit: Lenovo LOQ 15IRX10 Unbiased Review - Still The Best Budget Friendly Gaming Laptop?
Got my hands on the RTX 50 series [Lenovo LOQ ](https://www.amazon.com/Lenovo-LOQ-15IRX10-i5-13450HX-Backlit/dp/B0FNN465T6?crid=39HQ8VG01A7EE&amp;dib=eyJ2IjoiMSJ9.JXI3BB9a2R7mIigTvzfDhPP7kb_GzWTmWWRO-MOU4xKn0k4lHx7l9wQA7mIvXPhKB5UxlQS8U1ss12edmyJd8Fd2pFf2jTRNryBxvR2QrDFv-H2eQeL_6NbWK3BkS_JP9eIu6D_gS8xhY2IyGUCRbWn3AVybDpjBavEedXQ4WF8Sm1XzULG6qRPpEo4OZQTeCWlHqPf4mIuzerTl7R0wnW9pRxqj1RCEZ1YSX9-n1Go.Jxk5Hum3PluTAEyXJ6F9btlSeDymGWRGestgNu5ptYg&amp;dib_tag=se&amp;keywords=lenovo%2Bloq&amp;qid=1759686369&amp;sprefix=lenovo%2Bloq%2Caps%2C96&amp;sr=8-2-spons&amp;sp_csd=d2lkZ2V0TmFtZT1zcF9hdGY&amp;th=1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=taohid0f-20&amp;linkId=6b1ab50554dfae8958603caf3df6197f&amp;language=en_US&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl)and ran some tests on it at my workplace, I know the Lenovo LOQ is regarded as the best budget friendly gaming laptop, so heres a informational review about it. Keep in mind I put in whatever info I think were useful and not all, so feel free to ask questions below :)

# TL:DR 

If you can get it for a similar price or lower than the current one I linked, it is still the **BEST** budget friendly gaming laptop. Much better thermals than competitors, build quality is not as bad. But it has horrible battery life (expected) and pretty heavy. 

# Quick Specs (unit tested)

* CPU: Intel Core i5-13450HX (4 P-cores + 8 E-cores, Turbo multi up to \~4.6–4.8 GHz)
* GPU: NVIDIA GeForce RTX 5050 Laptop
* RAM: 16 GB DDR5 (single stick or dual-channel depending on the unit)
* Storage: 1 TB NVMe SSD
* Display: 15.6" FHD (1920×1080) 144 Hz IPS, matte finish
* Extras: Backlit keyboard, decent port selection, bundled laptop cooler (bundle)
* Chassis: Mostly plastic / mixed materials, thicker design typical for budget gaming

# Benchmarks (my runs + what’s realistic)

These are approximate based on my tests and expectations for this hardware class:

* **Cinebench R23 Multi**: \~11,500 pts
* **Cinebench R23 Single**: \~1,950 pts
* **Geekbench 6 (Multi)**: \~9,000
* **Geekbench 6 (Single)**: \~2,200
* **3DMark Time Spy (Graphics Score)**: \~5,500 – 6,500
* **PCMark 10 (Overall)**: \~5,200
* **Battery (mixed use)**: \~3–5 hours (web, docs, light gaming off plugged in)

These numbers are modest compared to high-end gaming rigs, but acceptable for 1080p competitive play and general use.

# Performance (Real-world Impressions)

# Gaming

I tested a handful of modern titles:

* *Valorant / CS2*: Easily 200+ FPS on high settings, 144 Hz fully usable. 300+FPS On Comp Settings
* *Shadow of the Tomb Raider*: High preset (\~1080p) gave \~80–100 fps.
* *Cyberpunk 2077*: On medium / DLSS / RT off, got \~50–65 fps in many scenes—playable but with compromises.
* *Assassin’s Creed Mirage / other open-world*: \~60–80 fps on balanced settings.
* *Fortnite (Performance Mode):* Easy stable 144FPS through out

Overall, the RTX 5050 isn’t a monster GPU, but it’s decent for 1080p gaming with some settings trimmed. It handles esport titles extremely well, and can manage modern AAA titles if you accept some lowering in effects or quality. The 144 Hz panel is appropriate for its performance range.

# Productivity / Everyday Use

Browser tabs, VS Code, streaming, office work – all felt smooth. The i5-HX CPU handles multitasking well, though putting too many heavy apps + games at once will saturate 16 GB and cause occasional stutters. The SSD is fast for everyday loads and large transfers, though sustained copy tasks will warm it up.

# Thermals &amp; Noise

* Idle / light use: fans are mostly off or extremely quiet.
* Under load (gaming or benchmarking): the fans ramp up to audible levels (but not screaming).
* Surface temps: the keyboard area warms under load, especially near the top row, but palm rests remain usable. Under prolonged stress, underside hotspots (\~45–50 °C) appear.
* Throttling: I saw modest frequency drops when pushing both CPU + GPU hard for extended periods also expected in this class.

The bundled cooler in the bundle helped drop temps a few degrees and keep fan noise lower during long sessions, so it’s a worthwhile addition here.

# Battery Life

Battery is not the strong suit (common in gaming laptops). In mixed use (web + light gaming) I got **\~3–5 hours**. In full gaming mode, battery drops rapidly (1–2 hours max). Plugging in is necessary for serious gaming. Lowering screen brightness helps a bit.

# Display &amp; Build

The 15.6" 144 Hz IPS panel is solid for the price: decent color and smooth motion. Not wow-level (not IPS-OLED or high brightness) but entirely serviceable. The matte finish helps indoors. For competitive gaming it works well; for color-critical creative tasks it’s average.

Build feels “budget-gamer”: thicker plastic chassis, some flex in the lid and keyboard deck. Hinges are acceptable. The keyboard has decent travel and feedback for this tier, and the backlight helps in low light. Trackpad is usable but nothing fancy (plastic surface). The design is more utility than style.

Ports were adequate (USB-A, USB-C, HDMI, Ethernet, audio) — enough to connect a monitor, external drive, etc.

# Comparisons

* [ASUS TUF A14](https://www.amazon.com/ASUS-Gaming-Copilot-Laptop-WQXGA/dp/B0DZQHB8S5?crid=TTZMP9O2DKP6&amp;dib=eyJ2IjoiMSJ9.rTflZLBJjbJ_RxBMQ5nZm9EAPchU0DwyULsI48n5xSsnADybkabMsbY9646Td5VJZPIIxvXOxVrBaGLyHxJHQv8r9NhU1y3gXGM8vUd4fmMEn7A3-AwEPc2ijmdrw5dxTSOm0VO2cO4W3nJOZjgVdQJGjuYXU4loZ-qZ_muDawjMGRmRb579PF8_Z9_VUM8-4D2kvuZca_aiE1-mUxuvGnP10CQAaTxE2f9zt3toYbw.WStf93bYTHvf19hr2Jh7riqZV5VLoC6Mh7wSTYrMy-w&amp;dib_tag=se&amp;keywords=asus+tuf+a14&amp;qid=1759687237&amp;sprefix=asus+tuf+a14%2Caps%2C108&amp;sr=8-3&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=taohid0f-20&amp;linkId=d6f4ef4e28210a7f68ebfc1044ce1a87&amp;language=en_US&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl): Much better battery life (10 hours), worser cooling but better build quality
* [Acer Nitro 16](https://www.amazon.com/acer-Nitro-IPS180Hz-Display-Graphics/dp/B0FSQ2MZFK?crid=2Z9XAG3XMD0PH&amp;dib=eyJ2IjoiMSJ9.FoEtgdZ-17a8_SycXEwRUmhyWyPad-pO-B9AhfeZ3tou9yrxLfqEGemrvtWFN8dPbB2CXWiKeYsdCRV5wNzqsxToyU-W3P94ZjJeOCaMIAkt9dCIWS0W3COrQKrc1SxHYACKxs8RRzvA1JsM_yBANoEZ5FmCNgT1xHYzhRbQpl_D1ElaTi5CmnvbGOWbCccjYSAMAku4uEz_Zhbl5EYAKl55snQSIUjCccK9aWthzXA.XUiG-ZOy3kmNAfsI2t0IvDArxxGHYnNfywsBoP32n30&amp;dib_tag=se&amp;keywords=acer%2Bnitro%2B5%2Brtx%2B5050&amp;qid=1759687102&amp;sprefix=acer%2Bnitro%2B5%2Brtx%2B5050%2Caps%2C93&amp;sr=8-1&amp;th=1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=taohid0f-20&amp;linkId=acca023be983bae67e1e1b15733d8a4d&amp;language=en_US&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl)**:** Bit better cooling since it has more space, similar performance. Worser build quality and system management software.

# A Potentially Better Choice

If you can push your budget a bit, I would highly suggest going for the[ Lenovo Legion](https://www.amazon.com/Lenovo-Legion-Notebook-GeForce-Eclipse/dp/B0FGGBBYK7?crid=3NY9IKQT28O6Z&amp;dib=eyJ2IjoiMSJ9.mTi9eJgjmema6Qe8FaCHYTRLJTFH8cUQKq25PFAgnlz6zEqYvy-7mgwQqj2upPrHQ3a12CnHW9dIOx1_feUmtmxGoqTzhrM2OzjAuKrGpxWpbh4kGjF5cm7-9T4ZdrcTdZOnddiWPauKmSui9F3SWplCeC_JWtA40QAP3ThlmV4kYjHqyQqq1zbXn_hUdELuS0yhWUgeclW_uDkwjuP-TQ5ImOPojfesrvugwqymzc8.fYLgOWP90ArwWGF-E4s7D_1j5AAWx8dCBDpvIYGvajM&amp;dib_tag=se&amp;keywords=rtx+5060+laptop&amp;qid=1759686877&amp;sprefix=rtx+5060+laptop%2Caps%2C153&amp;sr=8-3&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=taohid0f-20&amp;linkId=e31dd311a2fc005f3225e98da808c98b&amp;language=en_US&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl) instead, much better performance+screen+thermals. 

Alternatively, check **ASUS TUF / ROG / MSI gaming laptops** in the same price range with better thermal designs or stronger GPU options. You might trade off battery or weight but get better sustained fps.

# Pros and Cons

**Pros:**

* Good 1080p/144 Hz gaming performance for the price
* Good everyday responsiveness and multitasking
* Bundled cooling pad helps thermal behavior
* Solid port selection
* Competent build for budget (mostly serviceable)

**Cons:**

* Build is plasticky and flexy compared to premium laptops
* GPU / CPU combo is limited for future AAA (you’ll need to dial settings)
* Battery life is weak
* Thermals under load produce heat and some throttling
* Display isn’t exceptional — decent but not color-accurate or high brightness

# Tips for Buyers

* Immediately **Use**[ CTT Debloat](https://christitus.com/windows-tool/)**, get rid of useless bloatware** (trust me it helps).
* Use the bundled cooler — it helps in long sessions.
* Set fan profiles to “Performance” or “Turbo” when gaming; use quieter mode for non-gaming.
* Consider upgrading RAM (if slot available) to dual-channel (if not already) for better GPU performance.
* Keep BIOS/firmware/driver updates current, sometimes performance/thermal improvements come via updates.
* Thermal Repaste every 1-2 years.

# Overall

The [Lenovo LOQ 15IRX10](https://www.amazon.com/Lenovo-LOQ-15IRX10-i5-13450HX-Backlit/dp/B0FNN465T6?crid=39HQ8VG01A7EE&amp;dib=eyJ2IjoiMSJ9.JXI3BB9a2R7mIigTvzfDhPP7kb_GzWTmWWRO-MOU4xKn0k4lHx7l9wQA7mIvXPhKB5UxlQS8U1ss12edmyJd8Fd2pFf2jTRNryBxvR2QrDFv-H2eQeL_6NbWK3BkS_JP9eIu6D_gS8xhY2IyGUCRbWn3AVybDpjBavEedXQ4WF8Sm1XzULG6qRPpEo4OZQTeCWlHqPf4mIuzerTl7R0wnW9pRxqj1RCEZ1YSX9-n1Go.Jxk5Hum3PluTAEyXJ6F9btlSeDymGWRGestgNu5ptYg&amp;dib_tag=se&amp;keywords=lenovo%2Bloq&amp;qid=1759686369&amp;sprefix=lenovo%2Bloq%2Caps%2C96&amp;sr=8-2-spons&amp;sp_csd=d2lkZ2V0TmFtZT1zcF9hdGY&amp;th=1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=taohid0f-20&amp;linkId=6b1ab50554dfae8958603caf3df6197f&amp;language=en_US&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl) is a solid entry-to-mid gaming laptop. It’s not going to crush every title at ultra, but for most 1080p gaming it delivers good fps, especially in esports or mid-tier titles. It handles day-to-day use well too. The real trade-offs are build, battery, and performance ceiling. If your priority is “good gaming performance without going into premium prices,” it’s one of the better picks in the budget/mid tier.

Reddit: If you bought a laptop with an i9-14900HX or this motherboard you should read this

I am NOT an expert or even intermediate with computers, so if any of this information is incorrect, please forgive me. I do, however, believe it is straight forward:

I’m posting this because there is now enough evidence to show a significant issue with the 2024 Predator Helios Neo 16 (PHN16-72) and other laptops using the i9-14900HX. If your machine is currently failing or even if it’s still working fine.

Intel has officially admitted to a product defect known as Vmin Shift Instability affecting 13th and 14th Gen processors. This was confirmed by Intel as a root cause of instability that leads to **permanent hardware damage**. While the focus was initially on desktops, reports from users show that the i9-14900HX which is a high-voltage mobile chip is hitting voltage spikes as high as 1.54V right before crashing, which is consistent with the desktop failures. 

You can see Intel's official root cause announcement at this link: https://community.intel.com/t5/Processors/Intel-Core-13th-and-14th-Gen-Desktop-Instability-Root-Cause/m-p/1633442 and a report from The Verge confirming the damage is permanent here: https://www.theverge.com/2024/7/26/24206529/intel-13th-14th-gen-crash-raptor-lake-root-cause-microcode-update-permanent-damage

Acer appears to be acknowledging this as a hardware issue. In community discussions, Acer support teams have been reviewing troubleshooting logs that show these voltage spikes and have moved to authorize full motherboard replacements as a standard warranty service. However, the problem for owners right now is the repair process. Service centers globally are reporting indefinite backorders for these 2024 boards. It seems the industry is transitioning to newer architectures, leaving the replacement parts for these defective units in very short supply. There is a discussion about these motherboard delays on the Acer community site here:
 https://community.acer.com/en/discussion/729034/mainboard-replacement-for-phn16-72-delayed-for-nearly-2-months-what-should-i-do

These posts are numerous. This is just ine example.

If your laptop is still working, you should be aware that Intel’s patches only prevent future damage and they cannot fix hardware that has already begun to degrade. Since Acer has acknowledged the need for motherboard swaps in these cases, and since parts are becoming increasingly extinct, you are in a critical window. If you wait until the machine completely breaks to file a claim, you may find yourself stuck in a 2-month backorder loop with no working computer. If you notice even minor instability or WHEA errors in your logs, you have a much stronger case for a product exchange now while the manufacturers are still processing these claims.
I am curious if anyone has actually received a working 2024 i9 motherboard replacement recently, or if we are all just waiting for parts that are no longer being made.

These are the laptops affected by the issue, with similar patterns of failure:

**ASUS: ROG Strix G16 (2024/2025) and ROG Strix G18 (2024).**

**​ASUS: ROG Strix SCAR 16 and SCAR 18 (2024 models).**

**​Alienware: m18 R2 and m16 R2.**

**​MSI: Katana 15 HX and Katana 17 HX (B14W series)**

Reddit: Akhirnya upgrade laptop setelah 7 tahun. Tolong review apakah rencana beli aksesoris2 berikut worth atau tidak

Karena jarang banget upgrade laptop jadi lagi honeymoon phase mau disayang2 nih. Berikut list aksesoris2 yang mau dipasang, kalau ada komentar atau tips boleh share ya. Misalnya ada yang ga worth, atau mungkin ada aksesoris yg penting tapi belum didaftar gitu.

-Pasang SSD tambahan 1TB. Rencananya storage bawaan yang 512GB jadi buat OS dan program2. SSD baru 1TB nanti buat isi media, game, dll.

* **Storage:** 1 TB PCIe 4.0 NVMe SSD

* **Ports &amp; Connectivity:** USB-C, multiple USB-A, HDMI 2.1, Gigabit Ethernet, Wi-Fi 6E, etc.
* **Chassis:** Mixed aluminum top + plastic bottom, but some models are fully plastic

# Benchmarks / Performance

Here are performance figures I gathered 

* **Shadow of the Tomb Raider (Ultra, 1200p):** \~90 FPS average in tests with Ryzen 7 260 + RTX 5060.
* **Cyberpunk 2077 (Medium):** \~30–35 FPS at 1080p / 1200p in published reviews. 
* **Far Cry 6 (Ultra):** \~82 FPS 1080p in tests. 
* **Red Dead Redemption 2 (Medium):** \~69 FPS 1080p in tests. 
* **Time Spy (Graphics score):** In that ballpark of other RTX 5060 laptop GPUs. (Tom’s describes it as “in line with other RTX 5060 laptops”) 
* **Battery / endurance:** In light use modes, some Nitro V 16 units lasted \~10+ hours in video/web tests. 
* **Display brightness / color:** One measurement for 165 Hz 1200p panel (in Nitro V 16 variants) measured \~391.8 nits peak brightness, \~77.4% DCI-P3, \~109% sRGB in tests. 

# Performance (How it will feel day-to-day)

* **Gaming:** Smooth for competitive shooters (Valorant, CS2), you’ll likely see 200+ FPS in well-tuned settings. For AAA stuff, you’ll push settings down a bit. DLSS or frame-generation helps.
* **Multitasking / streaming / creative work:** 32 GB RAM is great ,you can keep browser, Discord, streaming tools, editors open without much swapping. The CPU will handle compiles, encoding, etc., decently.
* **Load times:** The Gen 4 SSD will load maps, levels, and assets fast. Opening big files or game launch times will feel snappy.
* **Thermal throttling:** Under long CPU+GPU stress, expect some throttling (due to power/thermal limits), but for most gaming sessions it should sustain pretty well.

# Thermals &amp; Fan Noise

* Fans get noisy under load (Turbo mode). 
* The case plastic and build flex is a mild complaint in some models.
* Hotspots underneath \~45-50 °C in worst spots, chassis warms around keyboard top row. Palm rest stays cooler in good designs.
* The cooling design is acceptable for this segment, you’ll feel heat, but it's not a deal breaker in casual use.

Don’t expect miracle endurance. In light usage (docs, video, light gaming off battery) you may squeeze **5–7 hours** depending on brightness. Always game plugged in.

* Build is mixed: plastic base, aluminum lid in some variants. The lid flex makes it feel cheap a little
* Keyboard is decent for typing + gaming. No fancy per-key RGB in many versions (four-zone RGB).

Reddit: My Legion Go 2 Review
Hey all,

I made a post yesterday about how I was underwhelmed by the Legion Go 2's performance, so I wanted to follow that up with a full review now that I've had a couple of days with the device. This'll just be a good / mid / bad list, with an overall verdict at the end as to who I think this device is for, and who it isn't for. Quick disclaimer as well, my handheld up until this point has been the SD OLED, so this may provide an ideal review for those who are also thinking of upgrading from that device. So without any further waffling, here's my review, starting with:

  
**The Good**

* The display is great. This probably won't come as much of a surprise as I think the display is the main selling point of the device. It's big, bright and just downright impressive with no drawbacks as far as I'm concerned. 144Hz refresh rate, if you're able to hit it, is also a pretty big bonus. As an example, you can easily hit that in a game like Hades, and it's a significant upgrade when compared to the 90Hz display of the SD OLED.
* Detachable controllers are great. They're ergonomic, the finish on them feels quite premium and the buttons / joysticks are also a joy to use. 
* Thermals and fan noise are surprisingly good. Monitoring thermals when pushing it, it never looks to hit thermal throttling territory and the device stays cool to the touch in all the important places. Fan noise is about on-par with the SD OLED, which is to say that it's noticeable but never annoying.

  
**The Mid**

* Performance is solid, after some tweaking. Yesterday, my post caused a bit of a stir where I said that there are certain games where the SD OLED seems to be getting close, if not matching the LeGo 2 in performance. After some poking around, I noticed that the frame buffer was set to 2GB by default. Why Lenovo have done this is beyond me, there aren't many games outside of basic indies that use less than 2GB. After setting this to 8GB, performance across the board stabilised and performance in the games where the SD OLED was matching it, it was now pulling well ahead, so that was a relief.
* Ergonomics with the controllers attached is reasonably comfortable. The controllers are well sculpted and, despite its pretty huge size, it masks this well when playing all sorts of games. Not much more to say there really!
* Battery is also pretty good. I've been mostly playing with it in performance mode (25w), and it's able to last around 2.5 hours if the GPU and CPU are working pretty hard in games such as Diablo 4, for example. 
* Trackpad is serviceable, if it is a bit small

  
**The Bad**

* Windows gets in the way, as we've all largely come to expect. If you want a unbox-and-play experience, be prepared to overcome the standard Windows hurdles before you do so.
* The Lenovo launcher software (can't remember what it's called off the top of my head) isn't great. It's buggy, fails to launch some games entirely and often freezes and crashes. I've disabled it from starting up entirely on my device.
* It's HEAVY. I didn't think this would be much of a problem to me, but after having it in my hands for 20 minutes, I can feel my hands and forearms tiring. It's a large departure from the significantly lighter SD OLED.
* The value. For what Lenovo are charging for this thing, I think the value proposition is off by quite a margin. When other premium tier devices such as the Claw 8 AI, Xbox Ally X (rumoured) and the Ally X are a solid 20-25% cheaper, I think this makes it a hard sell, especially given the cons I've listed above. When you compare it to the SD OLED (which is more than 50% cheaper), it suffers even more in this category in my opinion.

  
**Verdict**

For me personally, I'll be returning the device. I think it's a good device overall, which performs quite well, has the best display on any handheld and from what I've read, is a significant upgrade over the original device. If that's what you're looking for, I think this device is for you. For me however, ergonomically, the SD OLED is the superior device, has a display that, even though smaller, rivals this, and the overall experience with Steam OS out of the box is vastly superior to Windows in its current state. Furthermore, the performance difference isn't so vastly significant that it makes it hard to go back to the SD. Despite the lesser hardware, the SD does make better use of its hardware overall IMO. Actually, now that I mention that, let me quickly put together some bullet points as to who I think this device is for, and who it's not for:



**Who Should Buy This?**

* You own a lower tier performing device, such as the SD OLED, and want to experience significantly higher framerates.
* You're already a fan of the form factor of the original and just want a flat upgrade. Performance-wise I don't think you're going to see anything too significant, but there's no denying that the display is a knockout. It looks superb.

**Who Shouldn't Buy This?**

* You already own a device with a Z1 Extreme or equivalent and want a significant performance upgrade.
* You have small / average sized hands (trust me this thing is an absolute unit).
* If you've tried using Windows on a handheld in the past and didn't get on with it, your opinion isn't going to change this time around.

  
I think that covers all the important stuff. If there's something that I've missed please do leave a comment and I'll get back to you ASAP.
